intro: Hesperis laxa, commonly known as the looseflower whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops and weeds. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its flowers are small, white or pale purple, and are arranged in a loose, branched inflorescence. Hesperis laxa is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a characteristic species of Mediterranean climates.
